28. Usage scenario: Re-open deleted Git branch

💯Score: 16    🔗Associated commands: [ None ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

▲ If you merged hotfix into master and it created a merge commit at aabbcc, then you can resurrect hotfix using:
git branch hotfix aabbcc^2

▲ The ^2 is shorthand for "the second parent". If you didn't create a merge commit, then just re-create hotfix using the last of its commits:
git branch hotfix ddeeff

29. Usage scenario: How can I save a git "rebase in progress"?

💯Score: 15    🔗Associated commands: [ git rebase, git tag ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

▲ Rebase = repeated cherry-pick
...--A1--A2--A3--A4--A5   <-- branchA
          \
           B1--B2--B3   <-- branchB

...--A1--A2--A3--A4--A5   <-- branchA
          \           \
           \           B1'-B2'-B3'  <-- branchB
            \
             B1--B2--B3   [abandoned]

▲ Conflicts are in the index
▲ But there's only one index
▲ Where you are now
...--A1--A2--A3--A4--A5   <-- branchA
          \           \
           \           B1'  <-- HEAD
            \
             B1--B2--B3   <-- branchB

...--A1--A2--A3--A4--A5   <-- branchA
          \           \
           \           B1'-B2'  <-- HEAD
            \
             B1--B2--B3   <-- branchB

$ git branch saveme    # or git tag saveme

...--A1--A2--A3--A4--A5   <-- branchA
          \           \
           \           B1'-B2'  <-- HEAD, saveme
            \
             B1--B2--B3   <-- branchB

$ git rebase --abort

...--A1--A2--A3--A4--A5   <-- branchA
          \           \
           \           B1'-B2'  <-- saveme
            \
             B1--B2--B3   <-- HEAD->branchB

30. Usage scenario: GIT: Appending a patch made after a few commits

💯Score: 14    🔗Associated commands: [ git rebase, git checkout, git reflog ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

▲ What happened
A---B' (master)
 \
  \-B---C---D

▲ How to recover
git checkout master@{1}
git branch oldmaster master@{1}

git reflog show master

▲ What you should have done
git rebase -i master~4 master

pick <hash-A>  <message-A>
pick <hash-B>  <message-B>
pick <hash-C>  <message-C>
pick <hash-D>  <message-D>

# Rebase <hash-A^>..<hash-D> onto <hash-A^>
#
# Commands:
#  p, pick = use commit
#  e, edit = use commit, but stop for amending
#  s, squash = use commit, but meld into previous commit
#
# If you remove a line here THAT COMMIT WILL BE LOST.
# However, if you remove everything, the rebase will be aborted.
#

31. Usage scenario: Reverting a broken merge and reapplying selected commits with Git

💯Score: 13    🔗Associated commands: [ git cherry-pick, git reset, git rebase, git checkout, git push, git revert ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

P-Q-1-2-3-4-A-B-C-D-X-Y-Z

▲ Revert the merge commit (safest but messier)
git revert -m 1 M

git cherry-pick 1
git cherry-pick 2
git cherry-pick 3
git cherry-pick 4
git cherry-pick A
git cherry-pick B
git cherry-pick C
git cherry-pick D

# M reverts some of A..D and 1..4
# !M undoes the logical effect of the merge

    A-B-C-D
   /       \
P-Q         M-X-Y-Z-!M-1'-2'-3'-4'-A'-B'-C'-D'
   \       /
    1-2-3-4

▲ Throw away the broken history (most dangerous but cleanest)
git checkout master
git reset --hard Q       # rewind `master` branch to `Q`

git checkout Z         # move to Z
git branch tmp         # make a branch pointing to Z
git rebase -i master   # rework this branch onto master

pick aaaaaaa Commit message one
pick bbbbbbb Commit message two
pick ccccccc Commit message three
# ...

git checkout master
git reset --hard tmp

git push -f origin master

▲ Finally

git rebase --onto HEAD^^ HEAD^ second-branch

# point your master branch somewhere that makes sense - maybe before either branch
git checkout master
git reset --hard first-branch^

git push origin first-branch second-branch

34. Usage scenario: How can I avoid an accidental dcommit from a local branch

💯Score: 8    🔗Associated commands: [ None ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

real_git=$(which git)
function git {
    if [[ ($1 == svn) && ($2 == dcommit) ]]
    then
        curr_branch=$($real_git branch | sed -n 's/\* //p')
        if [[ ($curr_branch != master) && ($curr_branch != '(no branch)') ]]
        then
            echo "Committing from $curr_branch; are you sure? [y/N]"
            read resp
            if [[ ($resp != y) && ($resp != Y) ]]
            then
                return 2
            fi
        fi
    fi
    $real_git "$@"
}

35. Usage scenario: Print branch description

💯Score: 7    🔗Associated commands: [ git config ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

#!/bin/perl

$output= `git branch`;

foreach my $line (split(/^/, $output)) {
  my ($is_current, $name) = split(/\s+/, $line);
  my $description = `git config branch.$name.description`;

  $description =~ s/\s+$//;
  printf("%1s %-22s %s\n", $is_current, $name, $description);
}

45. Usage scenario: git default remote branch with gitolite

💯Score: 4    🔗Associated commands: [ git symbolic-ref ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

#!/bin/sh

. $(dirname $0)/adc.common-functions

[ $# -eq 2 ] || die "usage: $0 <repo> <branch>"

if [ $SDB_WRITER_ALLOWED ]; then
  # this will check only for write permission on the given repository
  get_rights_and_owner $1 # this also set $repo variable
  [ -z "$perm_write" ] && die "You don't have write permission on $repo"
else
  # require a repository creator to change default branch
  valid_owned_repo $1
fi

# move to repo dir
cd "$GL_REPO_BASE_ABS/$repo.git"

# check for branch existence
match=`git branch | sed 's/^\( \|*\) //' | grep $2`
# this will check for an exact match in branch name  
[ "$2" = "$match" ] || die "Unable to find branch $2 in repository $repo"

# update the default checked out branch
git symbolic-ref HEAD refs/heads/$match   

echo "Head branch for repository $1 updated to $2"

48. Usage scenario: Git: how to merge modified files only

💯Score: 4    🔗Associated commands: [ git cherry-pick, git reset, git rebase, git checkout ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

▲ This is why it's important to manage your branches well, in particular to use topic branches and to merge upwards.
x - x - x - x ------------- X (master)
|\                          |
| x - x - x ---- X (paypal) |
 \              /           /
  x (bugfix) ---------------

▲ If you have already made your bugfix, and you mistakenly made it on master instead of from the appropriate merge base, and the history on master hasn't been published, you should cherry-pick or rebase it to the right place:
# If the bugfix commit is not at the tip of master, you can rebase to get it there:
git rebase -i <commit before the bugfix> master
# rearrange the list of commits to put the bugfix at the tip, save and quit

# Now either cherry-pick or rebase the commit to the right place
# (rebase is easier if the bugfix is actually several commits)

# Cherry-pick
# make a branch and cherry-pick
git checkout -b bugfix <SHA1 of merge base>
git cherry-pick <SHA1 of bugfix>
# remove the commit from master, assuming it's still on the tip
git checkout master
git reset --hard master^

# or rebase
# make the bugfix branch (assuming it's still on the tip)
git branch bugfix master
# and remove the commit from master (assuming it's still on the tip)
git checkout master
git reset --hard master^    # or if the bugfix is composed of n commits, master~n
# rebase the bugfix branch to the right place
git rebase --onto <SHA1 of merge base> master bugfix

▲ If the history has been published, all you can do is cherry-pick the bugfix onto the paypal branch, and remember to do it right the next time:
git checkout paypal
git cherry-pick <SHA1 of bugfix>

58. Usage scenario: In git, how do I remove a commit from a branch but keep that commit in a separate branch?

💯Score: 3    🔗Associated commands: [ git cherry-pick, git reset, git checkout, git revert ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

▲ Create a new branch from feature3. Then reset feature3 from the dev branch. However, if you have pushed these commits you will need to use revert
git checkout dev
git branch newbranch feature3
git reset --hard feature3

▲ Now if you haven't pushed to remote
git reset --hard feature3

▲ Or if you have pushed
git revert feature3

▲ Also, if you want to add specific commits to newbranch, like feature7 you can use
git checkout newbranch
git cherry-pick feature7

67. Usage scenario: How can I make this script reflect the branch status on PS1?

export PS1="$USER_AND_DOMAIN$SEPARATOR$WORKING_DIR"'$(git branch &>/dev/null;\
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then \
  echo "$(echo `git status` | grep "nothing to commit" > /dev/null 2>&1; \
  if [ "$?" -eq "0" ]; then \
    # @4 - Clean repository - nothing to commit
     echo "'$SEPARATOR$GREENBOLD[$GREEN'"$(__git_ps1 "%s"); \
  else \
    # @5 - Changes to working tree
     echo "'$SEPARATOR$GREENBOLD[$RED'"$(__git_ps1 "%s"); \
  fi)"; \
fi)'"$GREENBOLD] $WHITEBOLD\t\n$RED>$WHITE"

73. Usage scenario: How to discard stash pop in Git without dropping my uncommitted changes?

💯Score: 2    🔗Associated commands: [ git commit, git diff, git add, git checkout, git apply ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

git branch stash_data [stash hash ID]

[on `master` branch, with all changes]
git checkout -b combined_data
git add [your files]
git commit -m "preparing to revert a stash pop"

[still on branch `combined_data`]
git diff stash_data master | git apply

75. Usage scenario: Git: Change already pushed commit message using git rebase

💯Score: 2    🔗Associated commands: [ git commit, git filter-branch, git checkout, git log, git push, git replace ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

$ git branch backup                                 # backup your branch just for safety

$ git checkout <commit-hash>                        # checkout the commit trying to modify
$ git commit --amend -m 'Change message here'       # change the author name and mail

$ git log                                           # copy the new-commit-hash
$ git replace <old-commit-hash> <new-commit-hash>   # replace the old commit by new one
$ git filter-branch -- --all ^<old-commit-hash>     # note '^' before hash, rewrite all futures commits based on the replacement                   

$ git replace -d <old-commit-hash>                  # remove the replacement for cleanliness 

$ git checkout <branch>                             # go to branch HEAD and see if the commit is changed perfectly

$ git push -f origin HEAD                           # force push as history is changed.

77. Usage scenario: How to determine if a branch has no parent commits

💯Score: 2    🔗Associated commands: [ git init, git symbolic-ref, git add, git status, git rev-parse ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

$ mkdir tt
$ cd tt
$ git init
Initialized empty Git repository in ...
$ git branch
$ git status
On branch master

No commits yet

nothing to commit (create/copy files and use "git add" to track)

$ git symbolic-ref HEAD
refs/heads/master

$ git rev-parse HEAD
HEAD
fatal: ambiguous argument 'HEAD': unknown revision or path not in the working tree.
Use '--' to separate paths from revisions, like this:
'git <command> [<revision>...] -- [<file>...]'

80. Usage scenario: How to push a file inside a folder made in a github repository?

💯Score: 1    🔗Associated commands: [ git remote, git commit, git add, git clone, git push ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

git clone <repository_link> #(Https/SSH)
# make required changes to this cloned local repository
git add --all # stage all the changes
git commit -m 'your commit message' # commit into the repository
git push <origin> <branch> # push to the remote repository

# To list available upstreams of this repository <origin>:
git remote -v
# To see branch you are on:
git branch

81. Usage scenario: How to commit changes on an old commit et put it on top of history

💯Score: 1    🔗Associated commands: [ git commit, git reset, git checkout, git push ]    🌐Details (opens new window)

Example:

# from detached HEAD
git branch new_feature
git checkout feature
git reset --hard new_feature
git push --force origin feature

# from feature
git reset --hard HEAD~1
# make changes to C3
git commit --amend
# make commits C4 and C5
git push --force origin feature
